While the National Park Service's decision to ban snowmobiles from most national parks will decrease pollution (news article, April 27), it will not address the problem that started this controversy: the killing of Yellowstone's bison.

Bison use the groomed snowmobile trails in Yellowstone National Park, making it easier for them to leave the park in search of food. When bison step over the park boundary into Montana, they are either gunned down or trucked to slaughterhouses by state livestock officials.

Under the new proposal, the National Park Service will continue to plow trails for large passenger buses in Yellowstone. These trails will continue to lead bison to their deaths, and will continue to disrupt imperiled species like wolves and grizzly bears. To protect wildlife, Yellowstone must ban snowcoaches as well as snowmobiles.
MICHAEL MARKARIAN Exec. V.P., Fund for Animals Silver Spring, Md., April 28, 2000
